content.description: Sit start at the far left end of the wall, and traverse right across the wall to the end staying below the lip.
content.location: This is the far left arete on the steep, shorter wall that has a lot of edges and crimps.

content.description: Sit start matched on a rail. Move up left to a quarter pad flat edge. Fire out right to a good crimpbar, and make a slopey exit.
content.location: This is at about the midpoint on the shorter, steep face with lots of edges and crimps.

content.description:
This climbs the seam right of the obvious hand crack.  Like its neighbor, it would be a classic if longer and/or higher angle.   It's more of face climb with long reaches to wide sections of a seam that otherwise won't accept fingers.  You could probably gear this if you want practice with thin pro.    

  It is certified snake-free!
content.location: This is the striking seam right of obvious hand crack.

content.description:
This is probably Cape Ann's only real splitter.  It is on perfect, bleached granite.  If only it were longer and higher angle....  The first ascent likely belongs to a colonial era boulderer.  Regardless it's a pretty cool crack to practice your hand jams.  If you know how to jam, it will be really easy.    

  One other caveat: Snakes! In the crack!  Seriously. . . on my last visit this crack was oozing with garter snakes. A particular large one had wrapped itself around the chockstone at mid-height. The base is also filled with shedded skin.  As this face catches the sun and the cracks offers protection, it's a great spot for those ectothermically inclined.   If you don't like your jams slithering back at you, wait until the winter months.
content.location: This is pretty obvious once you find the boulder.

content.description: Sit start using the rock pedestal for feet. Move up the tricky arete to a highball finish.
content.location: This ascends the steep left arete.

content.description: Sit start the arete with a decent right hand crimp and your left on a slopey ramp. Move up to the arete, and traverse all the way left to top out.
content.location: This ascends the short far right arete on the backside of the boulder.

content.description: Crouch start the steel belly and face using a left hand sidepull/undercling and a right hand in the thin, vertical seam.
content.location: This is on the backside of the boulder.

content.description: This is a big block also referred to as Uncle Andrews. This boulder has some decent problems.
